title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective exhibit is on view at Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Maine until Oct. 11.
Steadman and Hunter S. Thompson's attempted yacht graffiti in 1970 is recounted during an interview about the exhibit.
The free exhibit includes 149 original artworks showcasing 60 years of Steadman's career, highlighting collaborations and solo works.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: About 40,000 adults in Greater Boston risk losing SNAP benefits under Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill.
The bill may affect 9,600 legally present immigrants' SNAP eligibility in Massachusetts.
Massachusetts faces increased SNAP administrative costs, rising from 50% to 75%, adding $58 million to state expenses.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution lost 3-2 to Chicago Fire, effectively ending their playoff hopes.
Revolution's Peyton Miller and Carles Gil scored but couldn't overcome early 3-0 deficit.
Coach Caleb Porter took responsibility for the defeat, acknowledging slim playoff chances.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election on Sept. 9 will narrow down mayoral and City Council candidates for the Nov. 4 general election.
The top two mayoral candidates will advance, while 10 candidates vie for four at-large City Council positions.
Councilors in districts 3, 6, 8, and 9 are unopposed, and won't feature in the preliminary election.

title: Maren Morris brings her divorce album to Leader Bank Pavilion
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Maren Morris performed her divorce album 'Dreamsicle' at Leader Bank Pavilion, focusing heavily on recent material.
The concert showcased Morris's themes of independence and emotional resilience, despite technical sound issues.
Morris mixed '80s-pop inspired production with recent personal experiences, engaging fans with her vocal performance.

title: Alex Cora provides injury update for Wilyer Abreu, doesn’t give timetable for return
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: Red Sox outfielder Wilyer Abreu is recovering from a calf strain, with no clear timetable for his return.
Manager Alex Cora noted Abreu ran recently, feeling better than before, but not yet at full speed.
Abreu's injury leaves the Red Sox thin in the outfield as the regular season nears its end.

title: What oddsmakers are projecting for Patriots, Drake Maye on eve of 2025 season
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots projected win total set at 8.5 with +115 odds to make playoffs in 2025.
Quarterback Drake Maye has +5000 odds for MVP and 3,330.5 passing yards projection.
Mike Vrabel favored for Coach of the Year at +600 odds; Christian Gonzalez tied for 12th in Defensive Player odds.

title: Patriots were reportedly among teams who checked in on Micah Parsons before trade
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Patriots inquired about Micah Parsons before his trade to the Packers, showing interest but not pursuing due to costs.
The Cowboys required two first-round picks and a significant player for Parsons, a deal met by the Packers.
Micah Parsons signed a four-year, $188 million contract with the Packers, becoming the highest-paid non-quarterback in NFL history.

title: Patriots reportedly told team staffer to not wear UNC shirt in team’s weight room
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots staffer allegedly advised to remove UNC shirt in team's weight room amid ongoing feud with Bill Belichick.
UNC reportedly banned Patriots scouts from its facilities after Belichick's contentious departure in January 2024.
Patriots owner Robert Kraft expressed interest in a Bill Belichick statue despite prior tensions with the coach.

title: Live updates from the Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Madison Lucchesi and Peter Chianca
bullets: The Seisiún Irish music festival is held at Suffolk Downs in Boston, featuring performances by Dropkick Murphys and The Hold Steady.
A three-hour rain delay on Saturday caused schedule changes, including the cancellation of Stiff Little Fingers' performance.
Dropkick Murphys received an extended curfew and performed a 75-minute set with audience interaction, despite earlier weather disruptions.
